column1: Antalya (Turkish pronunciation: [anˈtalja]
column2: from Ancient Greek: Ἀττάλεια) is the fifth-most populous city in Turkey and the capital of Antalya Province. Turkey in the "capital of tourism" as seen. Located on Anatolia's southwest coast bordered by the Taurus Mountains
column3: Antalya is the largest Turkish city on the Mediterranean coast outside the Aegean region with over one million people in its metropolitan area.The city that is now Antalya was first settled around 200 BC by the Attalid dynasty of Pergamon
column4: which was soon subdued by the Romans. Roman rule saw Antalya thrive
column5: including the construction of several new monuments
column7: and the proliferation of neighboring cities. The city has changed hands several times
column8: including to the Seljuk Sultanate in 1207 and an expanding Ottoman Empire in 1391. Ottoman rule brought relative peace and stability for the next five hundred years. The city was transferred to Italian suzerainty in the aftermath of World War I
column9: but was recaptured by a newly independent Turkey in the War of Independence.

column1: Antalya is Turkey's biggest international sea resort
column2: located on the Turkish Riviera. Large-scale development and governmental funding has promoted tourism. A record 13.6 million tourists passed through the city in 2019.

column1: == Etymology ==
The city was founded as "Attaleia" (Ancient Greek: Ἀττάλεια)
column2: named after its founder Attalos II
column4: still in use in Greek
column5: was later evolved in Turkish as Adalia and then Antalya. Attaleia was also the name of a festival at Delphi and Attalis (Greek: Ἀτταλίς) was the name of an old Greek tribe at Athens.  Despite the close similarity
column6: there is no connection with the name Anatolia.

column1: == History ==
King Attalus II of Pergamon is looked on as founder of the city in about 150 BC
column2: during the Hellenistic period. It was named Attaleia or Attalia (Ancient Greek: Ἀττάλεια) in his honour. The city served as a naval base for Attalus's powerful fleet. Excavations in 2008
column4: uncovered remains dating to the 3rd century BC
column5: suggesting that Attalea was a rebuilding and expansion of an earlier town.

column1: Attalea became part of the Roman Republic in 133 BC when Attalus III
column2: a nephew of Attalus II bequeathed his kingdom to Rome at his death in 133 BC. The city grew and prospered during the Ancient Roman period and was part of the Roman province of Pamphylia Secunda

column1: Christianity started to spread to the region even in the 1st century: Attalea was visited by Paul of Tarsus and Barnabas
column2: as recorded in the Acts of the Apostles: "Then they passed through Pisidia and came to Pamphylia. And when they had spoken the word in Perga
column4: and from there they sailed to Antioch". Some of the bishops attributed to the episcopal see of Attalea in Pamphylia may instead have been bishops of Attalea in Lydia (Yanantepe)
column5: since Le Quien lists them under both sees. No longer a residential bishopric
column6: Attalea in Pamphylia is today listed by the Catholic Church as a titular see.The 13th-century Seljuk mosque at Attalea
column8: had been a Christian Byzantine basilica from the 7th century. The Great Mosque had also been a Christian basilica and the Kesik Minare Mosque had been the 5th-century Christian Church of the Panaghia or Virgin and was decorated with finely carved marble. The archaeological museum at Attalea houses some sarcophagi and mosaics from nearby Perga and a casket of bones reputed to be those of St. Nicholas

column1: Attalea was a major city in the Byzantine Empire. It was the capital of the Byzantine Theme of the Cibyrrhaeots
column2: which occupied the southern coasts of Anatolia. According to the research of Speros Vryonis
column3: it was the major naval station on the southern Anatolian coast
column4: a major commercial center
column5: and the most convenient harbor between the Aegean Sea and Cyprus and points further east. Besides the local merchants
column9: and Italians."At the time of the accession of John II Comnenus in 1118 Attalea was an isolated outpost surrounded by Turkish beyliks
column10: accessible only by sea. Following the fall of Constantinople in 1204
column11: Niketas Choniates records that one Aldebrandus
column12: "an Italian by birth who was strictly raised according to Roman tradition" controlled Attalea as his own fief. When Kaykhusraw
column13: sultan of the Seljuk Turks attempted to capture the city in 1206
column14: Aldebrandus sent to Cyprus for help and received 200 Latin infantry who defeated the attackers after a siege of less than 16 days. Kaykhusraw would take Attalea the following year and build its first mosque. Christians rebelled and captured Attalea with aid of Walter of Montbéliard in 1212. Briefly restored Byzantine rule in Attalea was ended by Kaykaus I in 1216.

column1: The city and the surrounding region were conquered by the Seljuk Turks in the early 13th century. Attalea was the capital of the Turkish beylik of Teke (1321–1423) until its conquest by the Ottomans
column2: except for a period of Cypriot rule between 1361 and 1373. The Arabic traveler Ibn Battuta
column4: noted:

column1: From Alanya I went to Antaliya [Adalia]
column2: a most beautiful city. It covers an immense area
column3: and though of vast bulk is one of the most attractive towns to be seen anywhere
column4: besides being exceedingly populous and well laid out. Each section of the inhabitants lives in a separate quarter. The Christian merchants live in a quarter of the town known as the Mina [the Port]
column5: and are surrounded by a wall
column6: the gates of which are shut upon them from without at night and during the Friday service. The Greeks
column8: live by themselves in another quarter
column10: and the king and his court and Mamluks in another
column11: each of these quarters being walled off likewise. The rest of the Muslims live in the main city. Round the whole town and all the quarters mentioned there is another great wall. The town contains orchards and produces fine fruits
column12: including an admirable kind of apricot
column14: which has a sweet almond in its kernel. This fruit is dried and exported to Egypt
column15: where it is regarded as a great luxury.

column5: but continued to be a rival power to the Ottoman governor until the early 20th century
column6: surviving by many years the fall of the other great beys of Anatolia. The records of the Levant (Turkey) Company
column7: which maintained an agency in Antalya until 1825
column8: documented the local dere beys.In the early 20th century

column12: particularly Konya. Antalya (then Adalia) was picturesque rather than modern. The chief attraction for visitors was the city wall
column14: a portion of which survives. The government offices and the houses of the higher classes were outside the walls.

column3: 000. The harbor was described as small
column4: and unsafe for vessels to visit in the winter. Antalya was exporting wheat
column5: flour

column10: the city had seven flour mills. Wheat was imported
column11: and then processed in town before exportation. Antalya imported manufactured items
column12: mainly from the United Kingdom. The city had a Greek minority that made up 1/3 of the population until the population exchange. Antalya also had a tiny Armenian population which had a church on the street of "Hamam çikmazi" named Hovhannes Surp Garabed

The Synagogue was closed in 1948 and its exact location is not known and the Synagogue might not exist anymore. The Jewish community had 2 graveyards and one was located across "Donerciler carsisi"and was demolished when the area was opened to construction

column1: The city was occupied by the Italians from 28 March 1919 to 5 July 1921 during Turkish War of Independence. Large-scale development beginning in the 1970s transformed Antalya from a pastoral town into one of Turkey's largest metropolitan areas. Much of this has been due to tourism
column2: which expanded in the 21st century. In the 1985 singing diva Dalida held her last concert in Antalya.

column1: Antalya was the host city for the 2015 G-20 summit and the EXPO 2016. Five countries have their consular missions in Antalya including Germany
column2: Great Britain
column4: Belgium and Serbia.

column1: == Geography ==
=== Climate ===

The area is shielded from the northerly winds by the Taurus Mountains. Antalya has a hot-summer Mediterranean climate (Köppen: Csa) with hot and dry summers and mild and rainy winters. Around 300 days of the year are sunny
column2: with nearly 3
column3: 000 hours of sunlight per year. Yet
column4: the city receives over a meter of rainfall yearly
column5: a high figure for a Mediterranean climate. The mean sea temperature ranges between 16 °C (61 °F) in winter and 27 °C (81 °F) in summer. The highest record air temperature reached 45.4 °C (113.7 °F) on 1 July 2017 which normally averages as high as 34.4 °C (93.9 °F) and the lowest record dropped to −4.6 °C (23.7 °F) in February
column6: when the low average is as low as 6.1 °C (43 °F).

column1: === Historic sites in the city center ===
Ancient monuments include the City Walls
column2: Hıdırlık Tower
column3: Hadrian's Gate (also known as Triple Gate)
column4: and the Clock Tower.

column1: Hadrian's Gate: constructed in the 2nd century by the Romans in honor of the Emperor Hadrian.
İskele Mosque: A 19th-century Mosque near the marina.
Karatay Medrese: A Medrese (Islamic theological seminary) built in 1250 by Emir Celaleddin Karatay.
Kesik Minare (Broken Minaret) Mosque: Once a Roman temple then converted to a Byzantine Panayia church and finally into a mosque.
Tekeli Mehmet Paşa Mosque: An 18th-century Mosque built in honor of Tekeli Mehmet Paşa.
Yat Limanı: the harbour dating to Roman era.
Yivli Minare (Fluted Minaret) Mosque: Built by the Seljuks and decorated with dark blue and turquoise tiles. This minaret eventually became the symbol of the city.
Murat Pasha Mosque :A historic  Ottoman mosque located in the city center.
Aya Yorgi Church (Saint George Church):Is a historic church built by the Greeks of Antalya which is currently used as a museum housing exhibitions of historical artifacts.
Saint Alypius Church:A tiny historic Greek Orthodox church which is still currently a functioning Orthodox Church.
Sultan Aladdin Mosque:A historic building built as a Greek Orthodox church in 1834 and converted into a mosque in the 1950s and currently used as a Mosque.
Ahi Yusuf Mosque:A historic mosque built in the year of 1249 and is possibly one of the oldest mosques in Antalya or even the oldest.
Ahi Kizi Masjid: Historic masjid located in the old town.
Kara Molla Masjid:Tiny historic masjid built in the 14th century.
Balibey Mosque:A historic mosque built by the vizier Bali Pasha.
Müsellim Mosque:A small historic mosque built by Hacı Osmanoğlu Mehmed Ağa in 1796.
Antalya Synagogue:A historic Synagogue used as house currently in the Balbey neighborhood between Kavakli Masjid and the Balbey Kesik Minaret Mosque.
Mevlevihane(Dervish lodge museum):A Former Dervish lodge housing a museum about Dervishes and Sufism.

column1: == Government ==
The mayor of the Antalya Metropolitan Municipality is Muhittin Böcek of the CHP
column2: in office since 2019. For general elections
column3: Antalya elects 18 Members of Parliament to the Turkish Grand National Assembly.

column1: === Elections ===
Antalya has traditionally been seen as a stronghold for the Kemalist centre-left party Republican People's Party (CHP). Being the capital of the fifth most populous province in Turkey
column2: Antalya is politically strategic and has been a target for the governing center-right Justice and Development Party (AKP). The AKP unexpectedly won control of the Antalya Metropolitan Municipality in the 2004 local election. The AKP won a plurality in Antalya in the 2007 general election
column3: symbolising the city's political transformation from a CHP stronghold to a CHP-AKP marginal battleground in the 21st century. The loss of Antalya was a major political setback for the CHP not only because of its significance as a centre for tourism
column4: but also because the CHP's former leader Deniz Baykal is a Member of Parliament for the province. The province is divided into 19 districts.

column1: The CHP regained control of the Metropolitan Municipality in the 2009 local elections
column2: though the AKP won a plurality in the 2011 general election. The Nationalist Movement Party (MHP) also have a strong political base in Antalya
column3: winning approximately between 15 and 25% of the vote in elections since 2007. The city voted in favour of the AKP government's proposed constitutional reforms in the 2007 referendum
column4: but voted against the reforms proposed in 2010.

column1: In the 2014 local elections
column2: Antalya once again voted for the AKP
column3: with the MHP taking support away from the CHP by winning a record 24.3% of the vote. The CHP subsequently accused the AKP of systematic electoral fraud
column4: and the presence of government minister Mevlüt Çavuşoğlu at one of the vote counting centres drew strong condemnation. In the 2014 presidential election
column5: the CHP and MHP's joint candidate Ekmeleddin İhsanoğlu won 53.08% of the vote. The AKP's candidate Recep Tayyip Erdoğan won 41.63% of the vote
column6: and the HDP democratic socialist candidate Selahattin Demirtaş won 5.30% of the vote. Antalya was a hotspot for the 2013–14 anti-government protests against the AKP.The secular main opposition
column8: regained control of the Metropolitan Municipality in the 2019 local elections.

column1: == Sports ==
The football club of Antalya
column2: Antalyaspor plays in the Süper Lig. The team's home venue is Antalya Arena
column5: which was opened in 2015. Another football venue in the city is Antalya Atatürk Stadium.

column1: The city hosts a number of international sports competitions due to its longer lasting warm weather condition. Since 2006
column2: one of the four stages of Archery World Cup events are held at the Antalya Centennial Archery Field. It also hosted European Weightlifting Championship in 2012
column4: European Triathlon Championship in 2013 and World Kickboxing Championships in 2013.

column1: Since 2010
column2: an international multiday trail running ultramarathon
column4: is held on the historical Lycian Way. The event runs eastward on a route of around 220–240 km (140–150 mi) from Ölüdeniz in Fethiye district of Muğla Province to Antalya in six days.

column1: == Culture ==
=== Cuisine ===
Antalya's signature cuisine includes piyaz (made with tahini
column2: garlic
column4: and boiled beans)
column5: şiş köfte (spicy meatball which is cooked around a stick) spicy hibeş with mixed cumin and tahini
column9: and various cold Mediterranean dishes with olive oil. One local speciality is tirmis
column11: eaten as a snack. "Grida" (also known as Lagos or Mediterranean white grouper) is a fish common in local dishes.

== Transportation ==
The main transportation to the city is by air and land. Sea routes are still under development.

column2: the airport added a new terminal.

column1: The city has a main port at the south of the Konyaaltı.
=== Buses ===
There is a network of look-alike Dolmuşes that are privately owned and operated minibuses
column2: under municipal government control.

column1: Antalya Ulaşım
column2: a municipally-owned corporation
column3: runs the public bus system. The corporation owns Antobus and Antray. Antobus was started in September 2010. In 2010
column4: the city planned to increase from 40 to 140 more buses.Payment for public transportation was made in cash until the launch of a public transportation card

column7: returning to a cash system. Halkkart has been used for the transportation system since the summer of 2010. Halkkart is managed by A-Kent Smart City Technologies under the control of Antalya Metropolitan Municipal government. Passengers can use identified cards to take buses or trams.

column1: === Airports ===
Antalya Airport has two international terminals and one domestic terminal. In 2007
column2: its number of passengers on international flights surpassed the total number at Istanbul Atatürk Airport and Sabiha Gökçen International Airport for the first time
column3: officially earning the title of "the capital of Turkish tourism".

column1: === Antalya Public Transportation Statistics ===
The average amount of time people spend commuting with public transit in Antalya
column2: for example to and from work
column3: on a weekday is 63 min. 14.% of public transit riders
column4: ride for more than 2 hours every day. The average amount of time people wait at a stop or station for public transit is 23 min
column5: while 50% of riders wait for over 20 minutes on average every day. The average distance people usually ride in a single trip with public transit is 7.6 kilometres (4.7 miles)
column6: while 13% travel for over 12 kilometres (7.5 miles) in a single direction.
